same top of the stack reported there.

These problems all are related to the "EMFContext" not being initialized before some early startup plugins are invoking the EMF Resources to be loaded.

The Factory classes used for EMFResource, and URI Converter classes, are not registered yet, so the wrong instances are being created.

Without being able to recreate this locally, I can only speculate on a fix, possibly implementing an "Early Startup" class that ensures this registration is done first, but I would like some feedback to this approach.

Not sure if this helps, but I once had to debug somewhat similar problem -- a race condition which was very hard to reproduce and even harder to explain ;-). I ended up instrumenting the code at the place of failure with Dump.JavaDump() call (force IBM JVM to produce thread dump). Knowing what all threads were doing at the moment of failure helped finding root cause of the problem. You should be able to use conditional breakpoint which suspends entire VM too, if your VM does not have Dump.JavaDump or similar.

Observed that on startup with a java file open, two threads (main & org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.text.JavaReconciler) can be inside ResourceSetImpl.getResource(URI uri, boolean loadOnDemand) simultaneously requesting the same uncreated, unloaded, uncached resource. When this happens, duplicate instances of the project Resource (such as .settings/.component) are created, initialized, and added to the resource set. I believe this is the source of a bunch of follow on problems.

We've patched org.eclipse.wst.common.internal.emfworkbench.integration.ProjectResourceSetEditImpl to synchronize its createResource() method.  We're testing it internally, will add patch to the bug if it seems to clear up these startup problems.

I certainly agree with the importance of fixing this, but, seems like this approach has no underlying "theory" behind it, and may end up just "moving" the places where threading problems occur. So, my vote would be a -1 until there is something of a unified fix ... or, at least, until somebody can explain the theme to me at my 30,000 foot level :) 

I'll give some specific comments below, but as a general comment, if this is a "startup" problem ... or, a problem with waiting for something else to be done ... can not some explicit checks be put in to not even try some thngs until certain bundles are started, or until certain jobs are finished running? 

So, I found things I have questions about in all three patches .... 

1. synchronized(ModulecorePlugin.getDefault()){
Synchronizing on the plugin seems risky ... espeically if there's a chance it could be called during startup. Who else is synchronizing on the plugin? Or, is this just to prevent this one method from being re-entered from another thread? 
If the latter, then any 'ol lock object would do. If the former, I'd like to better understand what else might be "blocking" on the plugin instance. 


2. EObjectImpl
Is not this one of the EMF classes that are not supposed to be subclassed? 
Or, have I got is confused with another? 

3. synchronized (adapters) {
Maybe minor, unrelated ... but there is no check to make sure adapters is not null.  Are you confident it will never be null in this call?
